ARTICLE.TITLE: Hyderabad police busts online gaming racket, Chinese national among 4 arrested
ARTICLE.TEXT:
The Hyderabad police busted an online gaming racket on Thursday. (Image for representation: Reuters)

The Hyderabad police busted an online gaming racket on Thursday and arrested four accused including a Chinese national.

Sleuth of the Hyderabad Cyber Crime branch busted a nationwide Chinese-operated online gaming and betting activities worth over hundreds of crores of rupees.

Besides the Chinese national, police also arrested three Indian residents of Gurugram, Haryana and Delhi.

Those apprehended were -- Yah Hao, the Chinese national who is the head of Operations for South East Asia, Directors Dheeraj Sarkar, Ankit Kapoor and Neeraj Tuli.

The Central Crime Station (CCS) of Hyderabad police had received several complaints about online gaming and cheating on the website.

A case was registered under Telangana Gaming Act, Section 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) and 120 (B) IPC (punishment of criminal conspiracy).

During the investigation, it was found that online gaming was organised by initiating prospective gamers through secure telegram groups where entry was through reference and commission-based.

In these groups, admins used to indicate the websites on which the registered members can play games and place wagers/bets.

Investigators found that players were placing bets on colours in a game called Colour Prediction.

It was also revealed that the bank accounts and payment gateways were linked to several companies including Linkyun, Dokypay and SpotPay.

Further, it was revealed that to stay away from the radar of the Indian Law Enforcement agencies, the Domain Name Servers of the gaming websites are based out of China. The data hosting services are cloud-based in the US and are operated from China, while the entire technical operation is also run by the China-based directors/partners of these companies.

The payments were being routed through India-based payment service providers/gateways like PayTM and Cash Free.

An investigator said that the companies were controlled through a firm called Beijing T Power Company, which is based out of China.

Police said that that the total value of the inward transaction on the two accounts traced so far is nearly Rs 1,100 crore, majority of which is in the year 2020. The amount which is frozen in bank accounts as of now is nearly Rs 30 crores.

Most of the remittances have been transferred to different other accounts which are being traced and some of the accounts are overseas. Total overseas remittances known as of now is nearly Rs 110 crore.

It was also revealed that the accused were planning to register a company in tax haven -- the Cayman Islands.

Police suspect that the group is also involved in other cybercrime activities like Phishing, running banned apps and dating apps.

It was also found that 28 similar complain of cheating was registered in different states of the country.
